title: How to Test a Heating Element

steps.headline: Know the resistance of the element should be this can be calculated using known values:R = (V x V) / P  [Where V is the voltage powering the element, P is the power the element uses and R is the resistance.]
steps.description: (An example calculation is shown in the tips section)

steps.headline: Now we know what resistance we are looking for we can check the element.
Use a multimeter to find resistance.
steps.description:
Set the multi-meter to the resistance setting with an appropriate measuring scale selected. Measure the resistance by disconnecting the heating element from any power source, and connecting the multimeter leads to the terminals of the heating element. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}If the reading is the same or very close to that of the calculated value, then the element is OK and the fault lies elsewhere. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}If the reading is a lot higher than the calculated value, the element is failing and won't be heating fully. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}If the reading is a lot lower than the calculated value the element, it is failing and will be heating too much or not at all if part of the element has shorted or exploded.

methods.name: Testing A Water Heater Heating Element

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/11\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg\/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/11\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg\/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Disconnect the water heater from power source.
steps.description: If it has a disconnectable plug, unplug it. If it does not have a plug, disconnect power by turning off the power breaker or removing the fuse.

steps.headline: Drain the water from the water heater.
steps.description: Locate the water valve at the bottom of the water heater. Attach a garden hose to the emptying valve and turn the valve using a wrench. You will notice a relief valve near the top of the water heater, you can flip the handle up to open it. By doing this it will allow air into the tank causing the water to flow out more quickly.

steps.headline: Wait for the tank to fully empty.
Remove the electrical wires leading to the heating element.

text:
Testing A Conventional Element Know the resistance of the element should be this can be calculated using known values:R = (V x V) / P [Where V is the voltage powering the element, P is the power the element uses and R is the resistance.] (An example calculation is shown in the tips section) Now we know what resistance we are looking for we can check the element. Use a multimeter to find resistance. Set the multi-meter to the resistance setting with an appropriate measuring scale selected. Measure the resistance by disconnecting the heating element from any power source, and connecting the multimeter leads to the terminals of the heating element. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}If the reading is the same or very close to that of the calculated value, then the element is OK and the fault lies elsewhere. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}If the reading is a lot higher than the calculated value, the element is failing and won't be heating fully. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}If the reading is a lot lower than the calculated value the element, it is failing and will be heating too much or not at all if part of the element has shorted or exploded. Testing A Water Heater Heating Element {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Disconnect the water heater from power source. If it has a disconnectable plug, unplug it. If it does not have a plug, disconnect power by turning off the power breaker or removing the fuse. Drain the water from the water heater. Locate the water valve at the bottom of the water heater. Attach a garden hose to the emptying valve and turn the valve using a wrench. You will notice a relief valve near the top of the water heater, you can flip the handle up to open it. By doing this it will allow air into the tank causing the water to flow out more quickly. Wait for the tank to fully empty. Locate the heating element. Remove the electrical wires leading to the heating element.
sentences: Testing A Conventional Element Know the resistance of the element should be this can be calculated using known values:R = (V x V) / P  [Where V is the voltage powering the element, P is the power the element uses and R is the resistance.]
(An example calculation is shown in the tips section) Now we know what resistance we are looking for we can check the element.
Use a multimeter to find resistance.
Set the multi-meter to the resistance setting with an appropriate measuring scale selected.
Measure the resistance by disconnecting the heating element from any power source, and connecting the multimeter leads to the terminals of the heating element.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/41\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/41\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-7-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}If the reading is the same or very close to that of the calculated value, then the element is OK and the fault lies elsewhere.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-8-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}If the reading is a lot higher than the calculated value, the element is failing and won't be heating fully.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/59\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/59\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-9-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}If the reading is a lot lower than the calculated value the element, it is failing and will be heating too much or not at all if part of the element has shorted or exploded.

Testing A Water Heater Heating Element {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/11\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg\/v4-460px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/11\/Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg\/v4-760px-Test-a-Heating-Element-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Disconnect the water heater from power source.
If it has a disconnectable plug, unplug it.
If it does not have a plug, disconnect power by turning off the power breaker or removing the fuse.
Drain the water from the water heater.
Locate the water valve at the bottom of the water heater.
Attach a garden hose to the emptying valve and turn the valve using a wrench.
You will notice a relief valve near the top of the water heater, you can flip the handle up to open it.
By doing this it will allow air into the tank causing the water to flow out more quickly.
Wait for the tank to fully empty.
Remove the electrical wires leading to the heating element.
